9c47e176-1fb6-4afd-ae41-0a7339d75477.description: The faculty or staff member is able to list and discuss a variety of learning activities, best practices, and instructional tools. These activities and practices will promote interaction (student-instructor interaction, student-student interaction, student-content interaction, and student-interface interaction) which is useful in a remote setting. This faculty or staff member can also use effective tools that promote engagement and increase motivation towards successful completion of courses.

The resources include but are not limited to instructional materials such as narrated PowerPoint presentations, multimedia that aligns with student learning outcomes (SLOs), and open educational resources (OERs). Faculty and staff members will be able to provide numerous best practices associated with selecting appropriate instructional materials for their courses.

ffb50082-e62d-45ae-9aa5-0348d2b193a5.description: Universal design was the focus of this session where faculty and staff members learned various strategies to provide an inclusive online environment. For example, faculty and staff learned how to provide a sound course navigation for students and ways to utilize multimedia to assist diverse learners. Additionally, there were strategies and best practices shared about how to promote neurodiversity and inclusion to encourage student success.

efb69bd1-6924-4ddd-9c50-3f99df8c23a5.description: Faculty and staff are able to explore and examine strategies to effectively communicate with their students in a remote learning environment. Attendees share and discuss different techniques to communicate online learning expectations, promote student-instructor communication, provide consistent support, and identify academic and student support services. Furthermore, the participants explore the technological tools available to them to enhance student-instructor interaction.

cdc4b33f-3e84-4646-96a1-41f21eea515f.description: The faculty and staff that participated in this session can discuss the ways to formally assess online students. Strategies and best practices were discussed such as how to create authentic assessments using rubrics for assignments and projects. In addition, plagiarism detention systems such as Turnitin were discussed as a way to deter student academic misconduct. A description of ways to utilize synchronous and asynchronous formats to support student presentations was also explained.

d49715be-f78a-47c6-8105-ef9ad7a9b48e.description: The faculty and staff members that participated in the continuity series gained a variety of skills that helped support online instruction during emergency remote teaching/learning. Participants were able to explore the five topics and they were provided a checklist that assisted with online course implementation.

b6615bc4-607d-4804-964e-c331ee9f2ad4.description: The financial services professional will complete seven four-week course modules with 270 hours of instructional content. The digital credential will be offered in tandem with the certificate to help recipients communicate their completion of the program via electronic means. Awarding of the certificate and digital credential requires the recipient to have already received a baccalaureate degree. This is a standard practice required by the CFP Board.
